clean_story:
"What if?" questions.  Rewriting past choices.
The term counterfactual thinking comes from "counter" (against) and "factual" (what actually happened). It’s like mentally pressing rewind on a movie—then editing one detail to see how the story changes.
Most people use it without realizing. Missed your bus? Your brain might flash: "If I’d left five minutes earlier, I’d be on time. " That’s counterfactual thinking—simulating alternate realities to learn, regret, or plan.
Two types exist:
Upward counterfactuals twist reality for the better ("If I’d studied, I’d have passed").
Downward counterfactuals do the opposite ("At least I didn’t fail worse").
Both serve a purpose. Upward fuels motivation. Downward eases disappointment.
Example: After a car accident, drivers replay "If I’d braked sooner…" to avoid future mistakes. Athletes use it too—reviewing games to imagine better plays.
The brain treats these "what-ifs" almost like real memories. fMRI scans show the same neural networks lighting up for actual events and imagined alternatives. This blurring helps us extract lessons without repeating failures.
But there’s a cost. Overuse breeds regret. Studies link excessive counterfactuals to lower life satisfaction—like scratching a mental scab.
Three related subjects are cognitive dissonance reduction, the hindsight bias effect, and how AI simulates alternatives.
